Not Supported Ratification Poll for Pairwyse Licensure (MIP66) - April 11, 2022. - I was quite vocal against DECO.  My reasons were that Maker could easily do fixed rate vaults for clients, and Maker didn’t need to open up a regulatory rats nest by providing a fixed rate instrument (this comes directly under SEC jurisdiction in the US, which would mean geofencing of the product).  The price like Deco comes in very high at 8M in MKR, and 15% fees, for something that very few seem interested in.  Put simply it is a product that Maker doesn’t need, that has a very high price tag attached, that has little interest from investors at this point.   I am always willing to hear cogent arguments against my views but so far have not heard any really good reason.  The fact we already are paying Deco is like - if we have one - why do we need two fixed rate products? Now to a whole slew of expansion budget requests that I am denying on a matter of principle.  I have requested that CUs break on-going from expansion budgets and only one CU did this (David I want to thank you for doing this and will explain why I voted no to your on-going request after these). I believe that MakerDAO the ORG of CUs, delegates, and MKR holders (as well as DAI holders even if we don’t hear from them) should have a say so in every quarter putting forward ideas for where to grow.  These I consider ‘expansion requests’ as distinctly different from on-going operations.  This involves all kinds of new ideas.  My Maker3.0 proposal, The aggressive growth strategy, Singularity project, Events, DIN growth, PE growth, COMMs growth, anything that is adding to current things Maker does, or added features (like say delegates ask for a MIP to include travel funds, SSI, MKR vesting, health benefits etc for delegates - I mean like why not right).   The point here is all of these better things should be put before everyone at least 1 month before the quarterly review, and we all sit down and look at what the global budget should do, and whether we have room for an expansion budget. Then MakerDAO can do two things  If there is no expansion budget shelve all expansion requests to next quarter. If there is an expansion budget have the DAO in the forums rank choice vote on all budget expansion requests (these should have a time frame to completion and ROI estimates if implemented - even if negative).   Do the same RCV on expansion budget.   Take the ones and amounts that make ‘consensus’ and put them up for on-chain governance poll to be approved for implementation or not.   I would like my RCV 100%, 95%, 90%, etc funding levels to be included.  Point above is that I believe it is unfair for the DAO to consider these expansion requests independently and believe they need to be put together into a package so PE can look at what GOVCOMMs is asking for, or DIN, or EVENTs, etc. and look at these requests in conjunction with funding so WE ALL can decide as a collective how much, and where to grow next. For the above reasons I am rejecting all budgets that have growth components and requesting all CUs to resubmit their on-going budgets and to put forward their expansion requests for the next quarterly evaluation either on 6/1 or 7/1 this year. I also am letting the community know that while I am making a definitive statement about process here I am going to back it with NO votes until CUs and the DAO brings forward at least a first version of budgeting process here that segregates on-going expenses from wish list expansion budget requests. Hence for above reasons of fairness, and seeking a better process I am rejecting ALL of the following budget requests.  Not Supported - Ratification Poll for Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) - April 11, 2022  Not Supported - Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP63) - April 11, 2022  Not Supported - Ratification Poll for Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget (MIP40c3-SP64) - April 11, 2022  Not Supported - Ratification Poll for Modify Protocol Engineering Core Unit Budget, PE-001 (MIP40c3-SP68) - April 11, 2022 Now to the harder ones I voted NO on.  Not Supported - Ratification Poll for Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions (MIP67) - April 11, 2022 - I appreciate the work done by RWF here with the proposed Methodology for SFT and think this was a fantastic step forward.  The sheer length of this document and the short RFC period made it impossible for me to comment in detail to get some clarity in this document and to deal with some issues.   The clarity is about what is a SFT - I don’t think these were well defined in the document, and one other issue that stuck out was in the methodology that was related to RWA Asset Originators having a significant history (thinking if we adopt this it will basically kill Centrifuge/NewSilver, 6s, and certainly Monetalis).   After looking at this lengthly comprehensive document I realized I would have to spend more time on this before I could even make commentary.   One thing I think everyone has to realize here.  RWF documents - pretty much across the board require at least 10-30x more time to review than almost every other document.  Put simply I could spend a week or two going through these documents and associated links and then another week or two just thinking about them before being able to make decent suggestions on change.  The fact so few people commented and there was so little time to me means while important these do need a bit more time.  Is it a reason to say no.  Not really.  It was basically the concerns that if we adopt this methodology that the lack of clarity in some respects will lead to gaming and other issues later, and that some statements stood out as red flags to toss out our currently approved AOs with vaults give me pause for concern.   It is likely I will add here as I read through these more carefully but will likely post in the threads. Finally - David I promised I’d come back to why I voted NO on your on-going budget request (thank you for taking initiative on this - GOVCOMMs along with GOVALPHA pretty much are high on my list of CUs really trying to do right things and I wanted you to know from me I appreciate this very much!)  Not Supported Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP62) - April 11, 2022 - Why?   30% budget increase red - flagged me here.   It made me look a lot more carefully at why a 158K increase on a 515K previous budget.   The standouts.  8-80K for operations.  This is a 1% to almost 16% cost component that really is huge. This seems like a huge jump here (while you try to explain it - the sheer size of this one component needs to be dealt with in some other way).  It made me wonder what the hell happened last year (do that again or something).   Then heaped in here is taxes (which I presume is SSI or something like it), and we heap on top of this a 8% salary raise and 25K on 1FTE part time from 45K to 70K.   Then you bumped travel, while taking off legal.   When I look at this budget it feels like there is some padding going on beyond the contingency that is excessive.  If Maker has to deal with 30% on-going budget increases from all CUs - just to run here.   If you had somehow gotten this down to 15% with these contingencies and taken a hit somewhere to make it work while explaining I could swallow that budget even if I didn’t like it.   30% is just over the top, and while I have other reasons to deny your expansion is yet another reason why I would not approve your expansion.  You are already adding to your expenses dramatically. I really want to urge CUs with these on-going budget requests - get your house in order now - if you messed up - you are going to have to take a hit so you don’t end up submitting on-going budget increases of 15% or higher.  I want to see on-going budgets settle in to no more than COL or inflation adjusts so we can finally nail down the yearly budget so we all can figure out not just how much money we need to grow but how to spend that to get the ROI growth in revenues we need to cover the on-going costs associated with such growth. I apologize for length of this.  But as a delegate who see’s himself as the governor for MKR holders I have to stick my foot down here on this out of control CU expense budget growth and the only way I know how to do that is by saying NO to requests that I feel are out of line and ask CUs to go back to the drawing board.  I realize other delegates may not support me.  I don’t have enough Maker to dominate governance with my decisions but I am going to take what I do have and vote it as I see is in the best interests for ALL parties, not just MKR holders, but CUs, when it comes to fairness, and sustainable growth and I hope everyone appreciates the hard stance I am taking here and that MKR holders/delegates will support me in this move.   I am not warming up to get rid of CUs but I am putting CUs on notice - start getting your financial house in order, and yes please I want you to come forward with expansion requests and ideas, but back these with how this benefits us all and allow us all to weigh in together on how we grow this protocol.  It is time for us to come together as a community to create the tools we need to work in unison vs. 100’s of people rowing at different rates in all different directions.

Derek appreciate the comments. I think I have been very clear. I believe that all expansion requests by the entire DAO need to be put together into a quarterly bucket so the entire DAO can review them while also discussing on-going budgets and how much money can be brought forward for any expansion efforts  Expansion needs to be done via entire community, quarterly.  Ongoing - as it comes. Everyone gets all happy when they think they have a lot of money to work with and Maker at this point in time, without selling MKR or borrowing DAI, has a shrinking revenue pool to work with to grow much less back the system in case of losses.  Since ETHDenver the protocol has lost what 25-30% of revenue, and has seen expenses climb by almost the same amount (with no end in sight btw). I had to think about what to do here and I believe breaking on-going budget requests from expansion/growth requests IS THE ONLY way to get budgets under control and to bring the DAO together on growth initiatives.   I honestly DO NOT believe I will get enough support and this DAO is just going to keep increasing spending until we literally have to flop MKR low to raise cash or borrow DAI and by then things are going to get horribly ugly around this DAO unless a ton of cash falls on Maker from somewhere.   I have done this more times than I wish to admit with various intentional communities, and co-ops and am going to do everything I can to head this off now, and try to reset MakerDAO course financially to something ‘manageable’ that is NOT going to lead to ‘financing crisis’ if at all possible. I want PE to think about the manpower that frees up once D3M work is done, and perhaps L2’s may not need to come in as quickly (I just don’t think these are going to provide significant revenues so ROIs on L2 initiatives aren’t going to be that high).   I see RWA/RWF as the critical side and Maker is throwing so much money there without too much real return in sight I don’t see why Maker needs significant growth here much less where we get it from.   How much work will be needed by PE in this RWF arena, what are the other real initiatives that will require PE work coming up.  Maker3.0 actually was a longer term plan - as resources free up to work on something new while streamlining Maker2.0 btw. give everyone with idle time to propose new things to work on and talking about how to really supercharge Maker via incorporating new ideas in wide open Maker3.0 initiative. What Maker2.0 needs is ‘Efficient growth’, and growing as much productivity out of our limited funds.  If MakerDAO seriously considered my Maker3.0 initiative we’d probably have significant opportunities to raise DAI via MKR3, create some new excitement around doing a second Maker that has a different focus on DAI (i.e. what DAI3 could be as well as MKR3) with some clarity on what markets thought and if Maker2.0/MKR governance found they had a significant asset on the books to build some DAI resources, a means to build a cooperative second future Maker3.0/DAI3 that had strong synergies and differences to current Maker2.0/DAI perhaps I would be more inclined to grow PE and a few other CUs btw.    I don’t see any clarity here or any really serious initiatives to grow Maker to not 100B but to 1T and get us 1-10B of assets to work with (via surplus cash, and a real treasury earning 8-12% returns in defi like Karpatkey is doing for Gnosis). I am looking at bigger pictures here and I understand people have different views.  Been there done that for decades.   I see some difficult times ahead unless Maker gets its house in order, and the rowers pulling together vs. however, whenever and in whatever direction they want. I have not replied but I am a strong supporter of KISS principles and really liked what @iammeeoh  posted here.   Minimality - KISS principle There is so much going on everywhere it is becoming difficult just to keep up on it all (apologies luca for not having time to really review details on MIP67).   If we just keep doing this free for all on ideas and DO NOT start to separate what Maker needs to do from what everyone might want to do, this DAO, this project will get buried not being able to do anything.  I hate writing long posts explaining myself.  I like to keep things as short as possible, I no longer try to write up any proposals unless I feel they have a criticality and a significant positive result potential (high ROIs) that are easily actionable, most bang for the FTE buck.  Work insanely hard at one-page posts and limit these to maybe 1/day. I want to do things that are good for the world, but I am also aware that you can’t do good, if you can’t even pay the bills or keep the lights on.  I want to see Maker hunker down on what it needs to do, put CU/DAO ideas into a quarterly pot of initiatives so we all can discuss and rank these, decide, timelines, ROIs, funding and then move forward together.  Right now I see too many competing interests, too much ‘incubation’ and too little real execution on what we need and wish lists growing exponentially.   To be fair this isn’t because of PE - I know your team is working its ass off with a heavy plate of stuff atm.   But I feel like this should ease up here, because I see nothing dramatically big that is coming up for PE to work on to justify hiring extra staff only to what have to lay them off in a year?   Explain what will require so much work once D3Ms are done and L2 briding/wormhole is pretty much done?   The rest of this will just be details of how to reach to an increasingly fragmented TVL space via more and more L2’s sidechains, whatever. I personally would like to see a greater focus on Maker3.0 (don’t care how it evolves) and how Maker can do a different and better DAI ala DAI3 and focus on using what we have now with Maker2.0 to be efficient.  Maker3.0 is freedom to finally so something really new, and big without any limitations, Maker2.0 has significant legacy and has the potential to be a reliable financial engine, DAI PEG to the $1USD has significant use.   Decouple two Maker systems and I am convinced the pair can be significantly stronger and much bigger, faster than the one. Until I see some real collaboration on the greater picture and, significant sustainable funding, I am putting the brakes on growth.

Thanks @MakerMan, I share your desire for simplicity and effectiveness myself. During the most recent months of my engagement with the community as prospective facilitator of Lending Oversight, I have tried to install in the teams what I have learned from 15 years in sophisticated finance. This includes the importance of good checks and balances, an open yet careful eye to what borrowers are proposing, and a pragmatic approach to “get things done”. Structuring and negotiation is way more boring than painting a bright decentralised and profitable future on forum, but not less important. For this reason, we have tried to educate, communicate, analyse, accelerate, as much as possible what was on RWF’s table, in order to position the DAO in the best possible place to (i) avoid nasty surprises, (ii) growth in a healthy way by onboarding new real-world collateral. However, at the same time, as you know well, RWF-001 and others have been accused of lack of transparency over process and methodology, and lack of communication over prioritisation and existing activities. It is a difficult balance, but either one or the other. For this reason, the existing MIP67 (and underlying methodology) that I incentivised RWF-001 to put together and that I grandfathered in its content, goes in the direction of sharing what is happening behind the curtain while RWF-001 and others work on a proposal. We hope that this would act as a map for prospective counterparties who want to know what is Maker looking for with clarity and detail. We have received feedback that it does. Ultimately, we remain open for feedback and are looking forward to improve what we propose to the community. Independently from the outcome of MIP67, we will continue to do so.

Hi @MakerMan Thank you for your thinking on MIP65 and MIP68. Please allow me to add a some colour for your consideration on your “Main comment” - i.e. the team and its ability to deliver results. I hope I can show you we have not taken the team-building for performance lightly, but taken quite considerate steps to ensure we have a performing team. Firstly I’d like to differentiate between MIP65/Clydesdale and MIP68/Lusitano, because the skills required to do each well are a bit different, but overlap: MIP65 requires Monetalis to:  Setup an appropriate operational structure (legal, trustee, 3rd parties, reporting, monitoring, cashflow structure setup, etc) approved by LTS and acceptable to a top tier asset managers Execute a bond allocation strategy that is approved by SF with substantive Maker community input Allocated accordingly to a set of top tier professional asset managers for the actual investing and management. The asset managers, so far, we have convinced to design and consider potentially executing an investment strategy for Maker are Baillie-Gifford, BlackRock and Goldman Sachs.  So certainly the actual asset managers doing the investing (and the proposals they make to Maker) should reasonably meet your requirement for a “Manager with 20 to 25 years real experience” I’d think. But does Monetalis have the skills to execute and operate this TradFi/Maker integration point? And help evolve it over time for Maker? And can we convince good asset managers to work with us/Maker? And do we know how to help Maker monitor investment performance and integration point? Well - personally I have setup many complex structures and got them to work as part of my private equity career - and I have worked with quite a few insurers on developing and operating appropriate asset allocation strategies. Other members of the team certainly also have complex structuring and operating experience from structured credit. So far, the asset managers we have found and got to collaborate seem appropriately top tier and engaging. And our collaboration with SFCU and LTS is well on-track. So all in all, I’d venture we are well set for executing, succesfully, on MIP65. MIP68 contains a repeat of the TradFi/Maker integration point from above and so I won’t go over again why I think we can execute that succesfully. But then, more importantly, MIP68 contains the building out of a non-bank wholesale funding business aligned with Maker’s clean money vision. Now, the team we have collected to execute this business is, in my most humble opinion, excellent - and all with many years of proven performance and track record in this particular industry. I would be very happy to present the team in detail to you, but, If I understand you correctly, then your concern is not so much about the individual team members experiences/track record, but whether they will be able to perform as a team? And it is an excellent question! It was, in fact, one of the first I asked myself when building this team. Allow me to explain. Some years ago, after many years in private equity and investing, I decided to try and setup my own private equity firm - I found a team and started a search for institutional capital. And thats when I heard your question the first time - and it was repeated by every single institution we met in the capital search: how could they know these skilled and experienced individuals would be able to perform as a team? (this story btw has a happy ending as we did find some big financial institutions that believed the team would perform). In this process I found out that the most common investment team dysfunctions that institutions worry about are roughly the following:  PARALYSIS: team gets overwhelmed by finally being at the helm of a fund and so worried about becoming the best performer ever that they pass on all investments put in front of them as “not good enough”. Money is not getting deployed. OVERENTHUSIAMS: the opposite of the paralysis situation. Team so hungry after investing that they just deploy quickly in a half-hazardous manner. Money getting deployed, but not well. Usually this type of team will under-manage their portfolio companies. HALF-BAKED: The team has not in advance reached a common set of values/ideas of what desirable deals look like and/or their individual roles and format of work. Creates infighting and lead to limited money deployed and often some very odd portfolios with varying degree of good management.  With this knowledge at the back of my mind I built the team out. For example: we have a youngster with only 15 years experience we really like on our team and with great credentials/track-record - I think he could potentially be “overenthusiastic” - so I put in a credit committee member I know he respects and I know won’t be overenthusiastic at all - also I know they won’t step on each others feet in terms who does what. And after building the team out we have been “running the team” to ensure it operates as it should without any signs of deterioration or distortions to prevent anything half-baked. Basically you start building the pipeline and start running the credit facility approval processes to its natural ends (approved/not approved) on the pipeline. And then we do honest team reviews along the way. I can tell you, in this process, over the past almost 12 months, in fact, at least one senior person was removed and replaced due to these reviews. In addition we have also made a choice to run our business exactly as all other wholesale funder does it. This further decreases chances of being “half-baked” - as everybody in the team then from the get-go knows core processes and roles etc. So all in all we feel quite good about this teams capacity for performance. It has been deliberate built for it - it is not just a random set of persons with strong track records put together. Perhaps a tell-tale sign to consider is that we have over the past month been able to build a fairly large pipeline, a good catalogue of partners and, in fact, a larger institutional capital partner willing to provide us substantive amounts of junior capital (USD 20M to start) and now also working with us on a program to acquire the senior debt portfolio we would build for Maker (to accelerate the capital cycle). These parties have all worked with the Lusitano team and been sufficiently impressed to decide to continue such work with the team. You might say you are only as good as the partners and customers you’re able to attract. And I think the team has done terribly well in that respect. So, all in all, I believe, the team put together to execute MIP68 will perform. This was a lot longer than intended, but you had a very good question that deserved a full answer. I hope it can help you a bit in deciding how to cast your vote. Please do let me know if you have other concerns or questions.

@Allan_Pedersen I felt your well thought and kind response deserved an acknowledgement and comment.   I have always appreciated your well thought out and professional comments.  Your general patience and approach with Maker I have always felt was ‘top notch’ in terms of engagement and professionalism. If this was just an issue with a ‘new team’ and group it might be a more simple matter.   I have covered with my various posts my issues, but have not collected the sum total of issues.  But I can make a simple list.  Rune as prior investor and associated with Monetalis (historical conflicts of interest were disclosed but still weigh generally when it comes down to ‘access’ and ‘prioritization’.  While disclosed this didn’t give a +1 to your case and isn’t a 0 now but still a -1 to me. Concern that a new business will come up against financing or other issues.   This could be particular issue if we get into a high rate environment where loose money starts drying up. Structure of the ‘deal’ where Maker gets 1/2 the rate difference, might be attractive to another financier (it is just too easy to work the books so Maker doesn’t get this bonus).  There was sufficient non-standard issues in the deal with Maker as to put the deal itself into a ‘special category’. While work is going on to get some equity backing it is just not clear to me this is sufficient. When considered against other possible deals (quality of the RWA managers) I just don’t think Monetalis offers some significantly better deal, nor has significantly better terms, backing, etc.   In fact in almost every real metric I can come up with Monetalis is something that Maker should only do as a higher risk type of investment that should have significantly better terms for the higher risk Maker potentially is taking on. Monetalis wants to position itself as an Arranger so is looking to use Maker to build a portfolio.  Personally Monetalis looks to not be able to scale the way Maker would need because it is a newer player.    IMO Maker should focus first on moderate sized deals with very high quality players, that could ramp to substantial size easily (without delay or other issues) because they already have the historical relationships and capital to do so.  There is a general temptation on my part to want to do something with Monetalis, smaller in size (like 50M) but I consistently get the feeling Monetalis doesn’t want to start small, and also that it simply is so raw/new that it will be too easy for Maker to be a dominant part of Monetalis.  I would prefer to start with 50-100M with a player that already has Billions in other deals going, that could ramp easily to 500-1000M and not have Maker be a substantial part of their portfolio.  I don’t think this serves Monetalis, or Maker. Monetalis is just too new, and playing in an environment that is very competitive and I am not convinced Monetalis is going to be able to bring the best deals to Maker, nor be responsive to changes in capital allocation (like if for some reason Maker wanted to move on a larger deal). As a small part of our portfolio ( say 50M) I am ok with it.  At 200M or more out of the gate give or take I just am not as comfortable as I would be with SocGen, Huntingdon, etc… I can’t emphasize enough Allan this is nothing personal against Monetalis, absolutely nothing against you or your team, but simply a view from my seat that Maker probably would do well to start doing deals with the most qualified, experienced, players in the space vs. taking on a new player.  I feel like Maker should have an equity position to do this but then if we take that on, we have conflicts of interest… Fortunately my position only is backed by so much MKR and so my vote alone won’t likely push this one way or another.  I just can’t in good conscience for MKR holders vote in the affirmative on either MIP65 or MIP68 and this is mostly due to my impressions regarding Monetalis and overall terms of the deals.   When I toss in the close rune affiliation I believe it is better to let Monetalis prove itself within the traditional space and to revisit any deals with your team after some time has elapsed.

Dear @MakerMan I appreciate the acknowledgement and candour. I particularly appreciate you setting out your thoughts and concerns so clearly. Allow me a few thoughts on them for your consideration. I here follow your numbering   As you mention, Rune is no longer an investor. His shares are put to the benefit of Maker - all proceeds accruing to his shares would go to the Surplus Buffer.  However, it is a plain fact that Rune and I remain largely aligned on thinking about Maker & RWA - after all - we spent some time discussing this. MIP65/68 are largely specific expressions of some of these thoughts over time. Any support in the forum from Rune - in the past or now - are merely consequence of alignment of thought and strategy and nothing else. I am rock solid confident Rune’s alignment in all actions remains solely with Maker.  It is a reasonably tough pill to swallow, when being somewhat aligned in thinking with Rune gives you a “-1” straight out of the gate. But fair enough.   I worry that you may be thinking about us a bit like a new tech startup. We are not quite that. We are a professional, experienced, investment team and have plentiful access to patient, cross-cyclical private investors from the investment/asset management world.  However, and in fact much more important in my view, MIP65 and 68 are designed, as all credit engagement should be: they are designed to be immune to manager failure. I.e. If Monetalis keels over, the Maker trusts remain intact and, for MIP65, any purchased bonds under MIP65 remain the ownership of the trust and can be disposed of as is seen fit by the community. For MIP68, any wholesale funding extended, remains in the ownership and control of the Maker trust - and automatically a pre-agreed backup manager is appointed (that has been shadowing the business since inception so they hit the ground running) and Maker can choose to run it off or potentially appoint another Manager to run it. This “emergency” process is then further smoothed out by the Delegated Maker Committee structure that we and LTS/RWF have been contemplating and designing over the past months.  Basically, in my view, all credit arrangements Maker sets up should always be designed to perform irrespective of manager health. Without having checked it, I am certain that current arrangements are in place, such that, for example should 6S or Centrifuge expire, all credit extended continues to perform to spec.   I wonder if there are some misunderstandings here. To be clear on the compensation structures in the MIPS:   MIP65:	0.15% of AuM fixed fee to Monetalis p.a… I.e. 500M x 0.15% = 750K MIP68: 	1% AuM fixed fee p.a. + 20% of profit after 2% to Maker. I.e. for example: 50M @ 6% portfolio return means Fee: 50M x 1% = 500K Profit share: 50M x (6% -1% - 2%) x 20% = 300K  I am hard pressed to see how these are particularly unfair or non-standard.    If I understand this point correctly, then I think my thoughts on 2. address this. Forgive me if I misunderstood.   I, of course, have considered how we compare to other deals on the forum - current or prospective. At the current moment, I would venture that both MIP65 & 68 should score quite well on risk, return, strategy and market conditions etc.  MIP65: We set up a safe structure w/LTS approval, ensuring money is allocated to top tier asset managers on good negotiated terms w/SF approval. The community is involved in the selection of asset managers and bond strategy to execute/mandate. I honestly see very little risk here. Not sure how this can be accomplished faster/cheaper/better - particularly given how far along we are with this project… MIP68: I have written so many details about this project over the past 8 months in the forum, that I really can’t add more to it. I know you have looked at the “lines of defence” note and it didn’t seem to carry the day, but I assure you it is quite a high bar we set there - not many will be able to reach it. You can try yourself and measure other deals against it should you find it interesting - you may be surprised by the results. Perhaps one note on the Manager vs Team: performance follows Team, not Manager - it is just a fact of the investment industry. We have a very good team - it will perform as any high-quality manager with a good team - and outperform one that might for a time be saddled with a mediocre one (which isn’t an unusual situation as a manager go through teams - the high performing teams have a financial incentive to go out on their own).   I think you have two point in here, let me take them one at a time: a/ “New = Not scale fast enough”: I don’t think I can reasonably agree on this. MIP65 is infinitely scalable from day-one of operations. You can go from buying 500M worth of bonds/mandates to 10B+ within a day. It is specifically designed as such. That is somewhat the whole point of the exercise of putting down the appropriate infrastructure for doing so safely via MIP65.  MIP68 is deliberately set in a segment that allows small, high-quality investment teams to develop large manageable, high-quality portfolios at pace. We have presented a pipeline of many 100M’s in detail. We have conducted due diligence on many to have the portfolios ready to go. We can scale quite rapidly - and continue to grow into the billions staying in this segment over the years.  b/  “Better Strategy = start medium sized w/High-quality managers and ramp up because they have capital and relationships to do so”. Let me address this a bit later in this post.   In the section below your list, you make a number of good statements well worthy of commentary/clarification. I will use a quote and response format here for simplicity: “There is a general temptation on my part to want to do something with Monetalis, smaller in size (like 50M) but I consistently get the feeling Monetalis doesn’t want to start small,” : MIP68 is exactly 50M with a possibility of moving to 100M. We listened to the community and did start small as requested. MIP65 is 500M - but that is a bond purchase execution program - rather different. “and also that it simply is so raw/new that it will be too easy for Maker to be a dominant part of Monetalis.”: I am hard pressed to see evidence anywhere of single source capital players in our industry under-performing. Rather I have seen some logic and argument that single source capital allows for further control, alignment and focus - note the terms of the bond acquired by the trust - the control points and involvement is above market standard to provide Maker with a better structure. I am guessing we are here talking about MIP68 rather than MIP65, because surely it doesn’t matter how many partake in the bond execution program - should have no impact on results whatsoever… “I would prefer to start with 50-100M with a player that already has Billions in other deals going, that could ramp easily to 500-1000M and not have Maker be a substantial part of their portfolio”: I just don’t clearly see much evidence of why this is a better strategy - quite the opposite. Firstly, I find it a risky strategy to work only with regulatory sensitive players where Maker is but a drop in the bucket. They can say goodbye any day of the week as regulators move in on stable coins. Secondly, the TradFi/Defi integration point is very young work in progress - very important to work with parties that are willing to deliberate work on improving this point and aligned to not take advantage of any loop holes. Thirdly, performance remains embedded with investment teams rather than managers - including access to unique portfolios - no particular protection in a Manager without the right team. Fourth, the ability to ramp up is not necessarily driven by size of the Manager, it is often, in segments more so driven by the investment team, the structure of the segment and the team’s access. Fifth, all the issues of working with Maker and processes around it and the need for having a “buffer” element between TradFi and DeFi (such as we are doing in MIP65 and MIP68). I think we stop there - we can have a very long conversation on this point if you would like at some stage. I dont think there is a right or wrong answer on this btw - merely an evolving strategy that will only become clear in action (“everybody has a plan until they get punched in the face”). “Monetalis is just too new,”: MIP65: I see no evidence that this would be better/cheaper/faster accomplished by say a “fund-of-fund” - the hard part is the TradFi/DeFi integration point, which in fairness is not something many have experience in. And we have gotten quite far in getting this project done. In this we cannot reasonably be characterised as “new” I think. MIP68: We deliberately chose a segment to enter where it is common that senior teams move out and build their own portfolios with no loss of performance - such that the consequence of being “new” is of no performance consequence. “and playing in an environment that is very competitive”: MIP65: Not sure how “the execution of bond investment mandates” can be seen as very competitive? I don’t really think it is. MIP68: A rather vast, and definitely unproductive, oversimplification of the market dynamics. Many factors play in your competitiveness in this market: long-term relationships with lenders, lenders need for diversification of funding sources, the current pull-back by banks from the market, credit class focus, your speed of execution, consistency in deployment etc - we are competitive today, as proven by the pipeline size and characteristics. “and I am not convinced Monetalis is going to be able to bring the best deals to Maker,”: MIP65: We would not propose the best bond strategies from the best asset managers? I think this is not quite a fair assessment of the status quo on this. MIP68: We have a large pipeline. They are all being negotiated to industry standard spec. We will scale and perform exactly as any high-quality wholesale senior secured funder in the UK. For someone being active in this segment that is exactly what one can hope for as bringing “the best deals” on to Maker. There is absolutely no sign anywhere that we would be bringing a subpar performing portfolio to Maker. “nor be responsive to changes in capital allocation (like if for some reason Maker wanted to move on a larger deal)”: MIP65: We can liquidate mandates within a day with the bond managers and bond strategies that are being considered. And we can move into new mandates the next day. That is about as fast as you can ever want to make changes in capital allocation I’d think. MIP68: This is a senior secured wholesale lender funding in the UK business. If we had the vault size and Maker wanted to provide a specific senior/super senior secured facility to a large Bank or Credit fund in the UK or EU, we would have the infrastructure to execute this - and very likely manage it. “As a small part of our portfolio ( say 50M) I am ok with it.“ MIP68: It truly is 50M with a possibility of extension to 100M we are requesting. At 200M or more out of the gate give or take I just am not as comfortable as I would be with SocGen, Huntingdon, etc… MIP65: I am merely executing and focusing on the TradFi/DeFi integration point and engaging asset managers - the actual investing/asset management is to be done by top tier asset managers. I think those I have proposed so far: Baillie-Gifford, BlackRock and Goldman Sachs, should amply satisfy your requirements for quality investors for a 500M portfolio. “I can’t emphasize enough Allan this is nothing personal against Monetalis, absolutely nothing against you or your team,” I am definitely not taking it personally. I very much appreciate you writing this and being specific. Only way we can get to the bottom of confusion and have factual, evidence-based, first principle discussions. Apologies for now again providing a long answer, but you covered quite a lot that deserved some more detailed comments and clarifications. It seems to me, that there is some “gap” between your reading of what we are proposing in MIP65 and MIP68, and what we believe we are proposing in them? I do sincerely hope we decreased this “gap” a bit with the above clarifications and comments. And produced some extra food for thought. We remain available for further questions, of course, over Sunday and Monday. We absolutely aspire to make it possible for you to vote on as full and complete an information-base as possible. Again, thank you for your very specific and direct comments. I think that is very productive!

Hey MakerMan, thanks for your feedback. We have been working actively on improving transparency on what we do, posting updates on the forum and using our Twitter account to talk about it. You can read a summary of GrowthCU’s accomplishments during the last year and the usage of our budget in this link. I’m happy with all growth we have pushed into the protocol, of course, it is not a GrowthCU only achievement, as everything in the DAO is thanks to work between various teams (community, delegates, CUs, MKR holders). As you said, onboarding wbtc was a great decision pushed by different people from the community and implemented by PECU. As with any collateral, our job is to find users for that ilk, educate the ecosystem about it, and use our force to spread the word (through partnerships, pr, social media, events…). Last year we saw a rise in its usage coming from Nexo and Celcius (  ). We have been talking with bitcoin miners (check ant alpha IV proposal) and institutions with large crypto treasuries about Maker Vaults, of course, the market impacts everything. Still, we are in an interesting position as a lending protocol, so we need to convert that into a narrative and showcase it everywhere. With the Makerv3.0 proposal, I agree with you about increasing liquidity because that will help our growth. LPs are outside our mandate, but we can bring partners to the protocol to offer these solutions with their unique implementations (wintermute, truefi, maple, karpatkey) And regarding events+SH+brand, we hear you, but we started with brand, as we think it’s an essential piece for the GrowthCU mandate. We support ecosystem events, but we don’t organize parties: that’s why we sponsor HackMoney2022 to find teams to build on top of Maker, we try to get a speaker slot on the main events, and have been organizing small-size dinners/lunches during the main conferences with our partners. Thanks again for your feedback, I hope we can talk soon to try to find a way to improve how we communicate what we do!

Branding, Events, etc. really going to lead to growth?   Now something never mentioned and @aburban90 pointed out to me what that Maker through swag, and or events has actually gotten staff.   I won’t name names because I think it would be good if people working for Maker could actually comment themselves on whether it was reach out initiatives like SH and Events that actually introduced and brought them to MakerDAO.    So in some way I think initiatives like this are important, but they should be measured balanced and well coordinated with some sort of tracking/rewards to measure effectiveness both in a hiring of talent sense, and a brought business to Maker sense (or even if Maker gets positive articles/press).   To my mind MakerDAO is adequately staffed for growth for the short term (6-12 months) and where I see actual tangible growth is already being worked on (D3M, wormhole, RWA).    The whole additional work on the ‘aggressive growth proposal’ seems ill thought out and doesn’t take into consideration the current environment in DeFI.     MakerMan:  Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Strategic Finance Core Unit Budget, SF-001 (MIP40c3-SP69) - June 13, 2022 (thread)   Changed vote here to a single choice:  Approve existing budget only (business as usual).  In many ways I appreciate what SF is doing both in terms of looking at budgets and looking at Maker from strategic point of view.   Various initiatives I have been a promoter of for a long time.   While I think Maker has enough money to grow various units given the state of the markets, the general uncertainty in budget accounting, and projections it makes more sense to look to normalize on-going budgets vs. adding more headcount until Maker has a better handle on exactly where finances are going.  I also am back to all budget ‘growth’ initiatives coming into a quarterly outlook cadence vs. every CU asking for more and tossing their requests at governance.  Put simply I want to see a better methodology for managing a global budget, how to claw back funds into a staff only surplus buffer (as independent from CU wallets and SB).  How to track budgets better.  How to give governance a choice and reasonable methodology to signal the desire to decrease a budget vs. eliminate it entirely (choice between - approve existing and rejecting simply put is not good enough for budget management because it does not allow for any reasonable budget reduction choices 5-10% say).   Because of all these factors while I might want to increase SF so we can get more eyes on budget issues, my concern is that SF is reaching pretty far with scope here and if the budget is increased might simply cause scope creep.  I really want this unit to nail down budget and finance reporting and governance itself to seriously consider addressing how the DAO in a fully decentralized fashion (no multisigs and software only controlled by governance) be able to build and manage a treasury, LP, etc.  See comments below.     MakerMan:  Ratification Poll for Permissionless Open Market Operations (MIP74) - June 13, 2022 (thread)   and     MakerMan:  Ratification Poll for Adding a Special Purpose Fund - Makershire Hathaway (MIP55c3-SP4) - June 13, 2022 (thread)   Changing votes here from Yes to NO: I want to thank fellow delegate @ChrisBlec for helping me clear through the muck in my own thinking.  I have been wanting MakerDAO for a long time to start building some secondary reserves both to earn some return, but also as a collateral/funding buffer to cover CU operations (to have a formal cash run in a place independent of the Surplus Buffer) that also allowed for some DAI liquidity management (via being able to use the collateral in Maker vaults to add or remove DAI liquidity via some sort of governance controlled open market operations).  The problem here is that in my zest to get something, anything going in this regard I disregarded what I consider key features of such operations.  Decentralization, security, and transparency.   The point here is that IF MakerDAO starts doing investments via multisig actions with limited actors deciding this in effect centralizes features of the protocol potentially bringing Maker under regulatory scrutiny and legislative action, additionally there are fund security concerns with multisigs generally.  This is particularly true of the Makershire SPV.  With respect to the Open Market Operations to buy and burn MKR.   I believe the DAO should have a real discussion of not just the conditions and amounts on funding burn, but the time frames and methods of execution.  Dsskiln acting in an automated fashion is useful but I believe we should revisit the methodology of how Dsskiln acts.   I would like governance to have conditions to start to operate, limit the amount and rate of DAI to be used, and to be able to construct a queue of items to examine when making a decision of where to put DAI.  In the end I want governance to have control over both the list of things to invest in, the amount of DAI to transact, the frequency of action, and conditions of actions.   Once these variables are set this Treasury function should be able to run independently of governance with the exception of how and when DAI funds are added or removed.   Because I believe I have acted with haste to get anything done on starting up MKR burn, and to create a secondary surplus buffer or treasury without considering the ramifications to Maker I am changing my vote to NO on these with the hope that the DAO will have a longer and better discussion of how to achieve the goals of both of these initiatives in ways that maintain, security, decentralization, transparency, using somewhat automated methodologies (i.e. smart contracts/software directed by governance).

PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - July 4, 2022 https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmefrhsE - supported  Select a Target Level of rNPI Profitability to Guide Budget Cuts - July 4, 2022 https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/Qmasg6zr - abstain.   Issue here is that without long term vision and strategy profitability can’t be decided.  EVERYONE will always want to be profitable.   The problem here is that while I was the first one long ago to signal to the DAO to pay attention to budgets and CU growth, I am going to be the first one here suggesting NOT to go overboard on cutting budgets to become ‘profitable’.   Given the strongly cyclical nature of crypto and Maker’s dependence on SC for revenues, not RWA it is likely at least for the next 6-12 months Maker may have to run at a deficit.   My rough numbers here is that expenses (without new CUs or expanded budgets) is running 30-35M/yr, revenues still falling at 15-20M,  CU excess DAI is 15M, SB 80M.   If I set next 12 month expenses to NOT exceed 40M, and revenues to be 10M, this leaves a surplus deficit of 30M.   Given CUs have 15M excess this ‘should’ mean no more than 15M extra expenses which means the surplus buffer drops to 65M MARK the above because I suspect it will be closer to reality in 12 months than anything else What this means is that by this time next year Maker should have > 65M in the surplus.  I consider that anything below 50M in the surplus poses increasing risk to the protocol but this number is arbitrary.  Certainly most people would agree that 10-25M Surplus with 1B in crypto assets, even 100-500M RWA has higher risk to the protocol.   Having closer to 100M surplus would be better. Ignored in above analysis is any liquidations, and huge expenses not accounted for and has at least 5-10M excess spend head room just for contingencies. All in all Maker should be proud to have gone from 100M in DAI to 10B DAI in 2 years.  crypto assets paying 18M in fees is a significant achievement.   This idea that Maker is financially strapped, and needs to cut expenses dramatically is coming from people who either don’t understand cyclicality, or would rather put profits, over people and continuous business operations.   Where Maker is now IS PRECISELY why I put my budget foot down so strongly now at least 3-6 months ago.  I think Maker can do better on how we manage budgets, and I also think working at Maker in a CU given this whole budget governance knee jerking environment would make me personally start looking for a different job (as a backup at least). This particular poll doesn’t take into account the kinds of scenarios I could envision and is looks FAR too ahead into the future (3 year run, honestly crypto barely can look past the end of the year). Comments A few general comments as to state of MakerDAO:  It was nice to see @Juan and SES come forward with some kind of alternative for DAO work via project management (will add link later). Implications of US sanctions on Tornado Cash I think are significant in the space.   I personally believe building a anti-fragile, decentralized, financial system using blockchain when considered in the context of TradFi from US regulatory perspective appears impossible.   Likely this is going to fragment blockchains and crypto generally into ‘black’ and ‘white’ which really is an unfortunate turn of events.  It is my hope that legislators will bring forward workable crypto legislation that will create practically realizable standards.  In the absence of that US citizens will be further marginalized and much of the world will begin moving away from the US Dollar - for good reason. Regarding the state of MakerDAO and governance/RWF in particular.  It has been sad to see battle lines being drawn between idealogies that are leading to various sorts of dysfunction and partisanship.  RWF is a classic case of serious and real dysfunction.  No matter how I look at this governance literally between rock and hard place with RWF.   When I attempted to kindly suggest to @williamr about making some sort of form post on RWF status and state of affairs I was told to ‘talk to Rune’.    It honestly would have been nice to see @Rune show up to at least one G&R call or even a Delegate Call but I guess that is too much since he can’t command the ‘stage’.    I see tons of people getting onboard the EndGame train and people even planning for it to come to pass like it is already passed,    Feel like I missed a signal request or poll on this subject.   Also I listened to hear the Hasu, Rune debate (not even sure I want to promote this debate) as I was pretty disappointed in both of them.  Rune definitely has a better command of Maker, Hasu made a number of statements that suggested lack of understanding of the protocol to my mind.   Neither case was succinctly made or well explained in the somewhat long debate imo and the views are distinctly opposed in some key areas that I don’t see being easily resolved. Lastly in my final days as a delegate I want to express my appreciation for the time I have been allowed to be at MakerDAO.  Many of you very kind and considerate towards me as well as helpful. The generally high quality of people, diverse views, and ‘with some minor exceptions’ the high level of quality discussions/debates and overall interpersonal respect.   It is my hope that some middle ground can be reached between the Hasu/Rune views and politics and best wishes to all working at Maker.  MakerDAO is one of the most unique DAOs and one of (if not the) most important part of the DeFI ecosystem and if any group of people can build anti-fragility, decentralization, sustainably it would be MakerDAO…  Best wishes and paths to success MakerDAO Maker Man
